This is free alpha. The second debate is almost certainly going to happen. Trump is COVID negative now and as dysfunctional as the US currently is, there are still strong democratic norms in place. The only things that could derail it imo are: 1. Biden becoming infected with COVID (very unlikely given his mask discipline) or 2. A black swan political crisis which creates so much chaos and rancor that it overwhelms the extremely strong norm of pre-election debates. I don't see either of these happening with much probability. A cursory glance at the 'smart forecasters' who have consistently beaten the crowd suggests broad agreement with this perspective.

One debate has happened, one debate has been canceled over not agreeing on format. That's leaves options 1 and 2. There doesn't seem to be a huge backlash to Trump cancelling the debate as I expected there to be, and Joe Biden presented really well in the first debate. It would be in Trump's favor to cancel the third debate as well to continue speaking to his audience directly uninterrupted through an open townhall style meeting that's broadcast nationally. Also, the covid-19 issue continues to be a big sticking point and its possible the Biden campaign may still want to avoid a face-to-face with trump in a week. Biden could also get Covid-19 and that could throw a wrench into this whole question. Alternatively, Trump will be better and it will be harder for Biden to make the case that the debates need to be virtual because more time has passed. I also still seems to buck a historic trend of presidential debates, and there is value to both not backing down from a fight and being seen as the timid candidate, so there is hope for a second debate still, as well as a potential for rescheduling the current debate. Right now I'm saying its a toss-up.

White House asked CPD about rescheduling the 2nd debate, since POTUS is purportedly "medically cleared of COVID-19" and no longer "posing a risk of contagion": "White House calls on Commission on Presidential Debates to reschedule second debate
White House deputy communications director Brian Morgenstern said the Commission on Presidential Debates (CPD) should get the second presidential debate back on the schedule after President Trump’s physician said he was no longer a risk to transmit coronavirus.     'The President is ready to debate and his doctors have cleared him for participating in public engagements. They’ve said he’s no longer a risk for transmission so it would be nice if the commission would get the debate back on the schedule,' Morgenstern told reporters at the White House on Sunday. Morgenstern said Trump wants to debate Joe Biden in person but if the CPD doesn’t reschedule the debate, canceled earlier in the week after Trump declined to participate in a virtual debate, Trump would do some type of public engagement that night, potentially a town hall event. Joe Biden has already announced a town hall event for Thursday, the night the town hall debate was scheduled to take place."
https://edition.cnn.com/world/live-news/coronavirus-pandemic-10-11-20-intl/h_e14d18d4154eeb54200c1001d840168e However, I think this is very unrealistic. "Bedingfield: Trump can't 'rewrite' debate schedule"

Trump is extremely unstable.  Right now it really cannot be determined if he meant it when he said he would not participate in Thursday's debate.  He might have been just ranting.   Yet, the first debate was really awful for him, and he does not well right now.  The claim that he will not participate because they changed the rules, I suspect, is a ruse or deflection such that he now has a reason not to participate that does not involve admitting that he is not well enough. He may feel that he can do better in the election by going to rallies instead.  I would estimate that there is about a 50 percent chance that he is too sick to perform well enough in a debate to participate.  I guess there is a 25 percent chance that he is afraid that well or sick the debate will hurt him.  Finally, there is a 25 percent chance that it was just all due to his ranting, considering his complaints about his most loyal aides made during the same Fox News interview.  If his refusal is due to illness, he might recover in time for the third debate.  If he thinks debates hurt him even if he is well,  he will not participate in both remaining debates.  I think the latter is more likely. The news on this one is changing hour by hour and sometimes by the minute.  We will probably know the answers to all of the above by Saturday at the latest.

So, I feel conflicted just explaining my reasoning as it seems insensitive in the current situation.  As such, I will just give the basic gist of it - considering age, rapidity and suspected extent of symptom onset, and existing risk factors a certain relatively high risk of not recovering exits. There are currently 3 debates scheduled in September and October, despite 2020 being an odd year, I do not see why there should be anything less than 3 debates.

In the past three presidential election cycles (2008, 2012, and 2016) there were a total of three debates between the front-runners (not including VP and non-sanctioned/unofficial debates). These all occurred either in late September or October, a period which is still over a month and a half away. So historically, it would seem 2-3 debates would be most likely, with 0-1 being virtually unheard of in modern political history. Biden has also committed to all three scheduled debates (he did so in June), further increasing the chances all three are held.
However, there are several reasons that less than three debates would be held. First, there is the pandemic, which will change the possible optics of a debate and won't allow candidates to exude as much confidence/competence (picture Trump following Clinton around the stage versus Trump crouched over in front of a laptop). With candidates swapping jabs about cognitive ability and old age, such optics may lead to one or both sides excusing themselves from later debates.
Similarly, Trump is currently finding as many ways as possible to get in front of cameras and speak to the American people. The debates would give him another avenue to do this. However, as we saw with his COVID task force briefings, he will forego the limelight if doing otherwise may tarnish his image (bleach, anyone?). So, if the first or second debate goes exceptionally poorly in one way or another (doubtful, but possible), we may not make it to the final debate(s).
Both sides benefit from wanting a debate, and both have high probability of a fubar in a debate.  I will refine forecast with more information.
